results.headline: Review: ‘Before I Fall,’ a Melodramatic ‘Groundhog Day’
results.summary_short: Zoey Deutch relives a day repeatedly until she gets it right in this film based on a young-adult novel.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Before I Fall

results.headline: Review: In ‘Wolves,’ a High School Athlete Can’t Outrun Clichés
results.summary_short: Taylor John Smith and Michael Shannon star in a sports film that transcends its stock characters for a while but eventually disappoints.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wolves

results.headline: Review: ‘Kiki’: The Vogueing Scene, Still a Refuge for Gay and Transgender Youth
results.summary_short: There are echoes of “Paris Is Burning” in this documentary, which chronicles a tight-knit community in New York. Yet there is a striking absence of elder mentors.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kiki

results.headline: Review: ‘Contemporary Color,’ David Byrne’s Ode to Color Guards
results.summary_short: An enchantment with these groups comes through in this documentary, which captures music and the backstage buzz of the performers.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Contemporary Color

results.headline: Review: In ‘Get Out,’ Guess Who’s Coming to Dinner? (Bad Idea!)
results.summary_short: This movie by Jordan Peele, his first as a director of feature films, is a skillful hybrid, blending genres into something terrifying.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Get Out

results.headline: Review: ‘Les Hautes Solitudes,’ the Silent Sides of Jean Seberg (Mostly)
results.summary_short: This 1974 film by the French director Philippe Garrel consists primarily of studies of young women, especially the actress Seberg.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Les Hautes Solitudes

results.headline: Review: ‘Dying Laughing,’ About Bombing Onstage, or, Conversely, Killing
results.summary_short: Paul Toogood and Lloyd Stanton’s documentary talks to comedians about the rigors of the road and other stresses of their profession.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dying Laughing

results.display_title: The Girl With All the Gifts
results.headline: Review: ‘The Girl With All the Gifts,’ and an Appetite for Flesh
results.summary_short: This thriller from Colm McCarthy, another variation on the zombie-apocalypse premise, combines philosophical debates with bloody tableaus.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Girl With All the Gifts

results.headline: Review: ‘Punching Henry,’ a Nice Guy Who’s Just Asking for It
results.summary_short: In this satire about a TV reality comedy series, its star, Henry Phillips, suffers one indignity after another.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Punching Henry

results.headline: Review: In ‘As You Are,’ a Nod to Nirvana, and a Loaded Gun
results.summary_short: Two teenage boys in the 1990s bond over alt-rock only to have their friendship strained in this first feature directed by Miles Joris-Peyrafitte.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of As You Are

results.headline: Review: ‘Bitter Harvest’ Offers a Clunky Lesson in Ukrainian History
results.summary_short: Prettily filmed yet parochial, this film follows two lovers through a mass starvation in the early 1930s.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bitter Harvest

results.headline: Review: In ‘Paraguay Remembered,’ Does Time Heal All Wounds?
results.summary_short: This documentary reflects on a legacy of political turmoil as the director, Dominique Dubosc, returns to Paraguay after 40 years.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Paraguay Remembered

results.headline: Review: ‘My Life as a Zucchini,’ an Oscar Nominee With Depth and Soul
results.summary_short: This animated tale of an orphan, freighted with the name Icare, or Icarus, is more charming than grim.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Life as a Zucchini

results.headline: Review: Guard the Sheep? He’d Rather Be a ‘Rock Dog’
results.summary_short: An animated movie for children is elevated by a fine vocal performance from Eddie Izzard.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rock Dog

results.headline: Review: Immigrants ‘From Nowhere,’ Anxiously Living Under the Radar
results.summary_short: Julianne Nicholson plays a Bronx high school teacher who tries to help three undocumented students cope with the threat of being discovered by the authorities.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of From Nowhere

results.headline: Review: Two Friends Dance a Wary Tango in ‘Lovesong’
results.summary_short: The movie, directed by So Yong Kim, explores the mystery of unspoken love.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lovesong

results.headline: Review: Ice Cube and Charlie Day Face Off in ‘Fist Fight’
results.summary_short: It’s the last day of school, and two teachers are getting ready to rumble in this comedy directed by Richie Keen.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fist Fight

results.headline: Review: ‘American Fable,’ Pastoral With a Wolf Howling
results.summary_short: Anne Hamilton’s film seems full of suspenseful promise as it opens on an isolated swath of the country’s heartland, but the story finds no traction.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of American Fable

results.headline: Review: James Franco Tackles Steinbeck’s ‘In Dubious Battle’
results.summary_short: Based on the first novel in Steinbeck’s Dust Bowl trilogy, this is a traditional historical drama with stale boilerplate dialogue. Mr. Franco stars and directs.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of In Dubious Battle

results.headline: Review: In ‘How Heavy This Hammer,’ Life Takes a Toll on Dad
results.summary_short: Written and directed by Kazik Radwanski, this film was shot in practically all hand-held almost close-ups.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of How Heavy This Hammer
